Graphical abstract Nanodiamonds (NDs), a typical sp3-like carbon, have an average size less than 10nm with a large surface-to-volume ratio, which contributes to a high surface activity than other types of carbon. However, the powder form of the material renders it difficult to use in large-scale applications, especially in the field of heterogeneous catalysis in which high pressure drop across the catalytic bed and difficulty of handling powder are the main drawbacks. In this work, a new hybrid structure consisting of nanodiamond-decorated porous β-SiC foam matrix has been investigated as a metal-free catalyst in the steam-free dehydrogenation of ethylbenzene into styrene. The hybrid foam catalyst displays an excellent catalytic specific rate and stability in the direct catalytic dehydrogenation of ethylbenzene (EB) to styrene. The dehydrogenation activity (12.87mmolST/gND /h, moles styrene products per gram of nanodiamonds per hour) is about 10 times higher with respect to the commercial K-Fe-based catalyst and 3.8 times higher than that of powder-form NDs without losing styrene selectivity (SST =98%) and thus demonstrates the high catalytic efficiency of this metal-free catalyst for the studied reaction. This study shows a new development towards the practical use of such structured composite catalysts in the field of catalysis where high performance and stable catalyst are still under scrutiny. Keywords Foam-structured materials Pressure drop Nanodiamonds Silicon carbide Metal-free catalyst Ethylbenzene dehydrogenation 1 Introduction Styrene monomer is a basic raw material for the production of polymeric materials such as polystyrene, acrylonitrile-butadiene-styrene (ABS) resins and a variety of miscellaneous polymers. Catalytic dehydrogenation of ethylbenzene (EB) to styrene (ST), which accounts for 90% styrene production, is one of the most important reaction processes up to date in the chemistry industry [1,2]. The widely used catalyst in commercialized process of EB dehydrogenation is K-Fe-based catalyst with high iron loading [3–5]. However, the carbonaceous species deposit on the active sites of the K-Fe catalysts during the course of the reaction induces drastic deactivation of the catalysts in a direct steam-free EB dehydrogenation process [6]. Thus, a high amount of steam is added to the reactant mixture in order to prevent coke formation through the combustion process with carbon. Steam also helps in maintaining the reaction temperature within the catalyst bed due to the endothermic character of the reaction. In such process, a large energy input has been used to produce steam which significantly increases the carbon footprint of the process along with the extra cost linked with the post-reaction treatment of the wastewater. It is therefore of interest to develop new materials with higher resistance towards carbon fouling and high catalytic activity as well for operating in a steam-free reaction medium. The catalyst should also be relatively cheap to compete with the iron-based catalyst used nowadays. Recent reports have suggested that nanodiamond (ND), which is synthesized by a high temperature and pressure detonation method [7,8], is a promising steam-free dehydrogenation catalyst, which could replace the traditional supported metal oxide catalysts [6,9]. Typical ND possesses the particle size around 4–10nm, showing polyhedral structure with almost 20% of the total atom number (NDs particle size less 5nm, for example) is exposed on the surface [10]. Due to the large number of surface defects and the large surface-to-volume ratio, the ND presents a very high active surface compared with that of other nanocarbon materials [6]. Unfortunately, the powder form of ND renders it difficult to be used in a fixed-bed reactor, due to the high pressure drop across the catalyst bed, and also for safety of handling. Thus, it is necessary to support the ND on a macroscopic support to generate macroscopic shape catalyst with easy handling and provide low pressure drop for catalytic applications. The macroscopic shape of the support could also favour the escaping of the intermediate products and thus contribute to the maintaining of the overall activity of the catalyst by lowering secondary reactions leading to coke formation. Silicon carbide (SiC) displaying most of the physical properties required for being used as a catalyst support, such as macropores with medium specific surface area, high mechanical strength and thermal conductivity, high oxidative resistance and chemical inertness [11–13], has been reported as an efficient support for various catalytic reactions during the last decades [14–25]. The foam-structured β-SiC with opened-structure, high mechanical stability and good intrinsic thermal conductivity [26–28] could be expected as ideal support for nanodiamonds typical in the dehydrogenation process. Solid foam has long been studied by Schouten and co-workers [29–31] in several gas–liquid reactions and showed enhanced catalytic performance due to the peculiar physical properties of the foam. Indeed, foam displays a relatively high radial mixing degree due to the presence of struts along the foam matrix which favours the rapid homogenization of the reactant flow. In such endothermic reaction, the high thermal conductivity of the support could also be beneficial for maintaining a homogeneous temperature within the catalyst bed. Recently, Liu et al. [23] developed a two-step method to support NDs onto the carbon nanotubes (CNTs) network decorated a SiC macroscopic host structure. The SiC macroscopic host structure, which was synthesized by a slurry coating method displays a relatively low specific surface area which, cannot be directly used as a macroscopic support for ND dispersion and thus, CNTs with high effective surface area are necessary to disperse the NDs on the composite. In our previously work [32], hybrid materials with NDs uniformly dispersed on the graphene oxide/few layer graphene (FLG-GO) are prepared for use as metal-free catalyst in the steam-free dehydrogenation of EB to styrene. In this system, the GO plays a role of support to incorporate ND particles through static attractive forces. However, the simple, low-cost one-step synthesis of a macroscopic NDs/support composite has not been reported yet. Herein, we demonstrate a facile one-step synthesis method to support the nanosized ND on macroscopic β-SiC foam (ND/β-SiC foam) and its subsequent use as structured catalyst in the steam-free direct dehydrogenation of ethylbenzene to styrene. It is expected that the combination of high voidage and good mixing foam and the nanoscopic dimension of NDs, with a high intrinsic surface area, in a single structured catalyst will lead to a high performance catalytic system with easy handling and processing. In addition, both nanodiamonds and SiC can be prepared in a large scale which could significantly reduce the time to market of the process. The catalytic activity is compared with that obtained on unsupported powder ND and alumina-containing iron catalyst promoted with potassium (90wt % of iron). The stability of the catalyst is also studied with a long-term catalytic evaluation. 2 Experimental 2.1 Metal-free catalyst preparation Silicon carbide (β-SiC) with different shapes was synthesized via gas–solid reaction between the SiO vapour and dispersed solid carbon [15,33]. Typically, the foam structure β-SiC was synthesized by using polyurethane foam (PU foam) as template, in which all the geometry of the foam could be finely tuned by modifying the characteristics of the PU foam template. The PU foam was infiltrated with a mixture of phenolic resin-containing micrometric Si and carbon black at room temperature. After drying, the obtained solid containing the resin, Si and carbon black was heated up in flowing argon from room temperature to the carburization temperature of 1350°C. During the heating from room temperature to 700°C, the resin underwent carbonization leaving behind a solid carbon skeleton containing oxygenated groups. At the carburization temperature, the oxygen issued from the resin reacted with Si to generate SiO vapour which further reacted with the carbon structure to form the SiC. The synthesis method allowed the complete conservation of the foam structure when passing from PU to carbon and finally SiC. The obtained SiC material was further calcinated in air at 800°C for 2h in order to burn off the residual unreacted carbon material. The commercial NDs in a powder form with diameter in the range of 4–8nm were supplied by Hightech Co. (Finland) and were used without any further treatment. The suspension of NDs in ethanol was prepared by using sonication process at room temperature for 2h. The formed dispersed NDs were deposited on the porous SiC surface through pore volume impregnation process and then oven-dried at 80°C for 12h until the complete evaporation of the solvent leading to the formation of the ND/SiC composite. The as-synthesized catalyst was further annealed in argon flow at 550°C for 2h before evaluation in the direct steam-free dehydrogenation process. The amount of the deposited NDs can be adjusted by performing additional impregnation steps followed by a thermal treatment. 2.2 Characterization techniques Pressure drop was measured on a sample bed with various gas velocities in the 0–5m/s range with differential pressure sensor (Keller Druckmesstechnik PD-41 (0–200mbar)). Gas velocity is measured with an anemometer Testo 435-1 equipped with a hot wire probe (0–20m/s). Thermal gravimetry analysis (TGA) was performed on a Setaram apparatus with an air flow rate of 25mL/min and a heating rate of 10°C/min from room temperature to 1000°C. The specific surface area of different samples was measured by the BET method using N2 as adsorbent at liquid nitrogen temperature (TriStar sorptometer). Before measurement, the samples were outgassed at 250°C overnight in order to desorb moisture and impurities on their surface. The XPS measurements of the support were performed on a MULTILAB 2000 (THERMO VG) spectrometer equipped with Al Kα anode (hν =1486.6eV), with 10min of acquisition. Peak deconvolution has been made with “Avantage” program from Thermoelectron Company. The C 1s peak at 284.6eV was used to correct charging effects. Shirley backgrounds were subtracted from the raw data to obtain the areas of the C 1s peak. The gross morphology of the materials was observed by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) on a JEOL F-6700 FEG with a lattice resolution of 1nm, at an accelerating voltage of 10kV. The sample was covered by a thin layer of gold in order to decrease the problem of charge during the analysis. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) observations were conducted on a JEOL 2100F microscope working at 200kV accelerated voltage with a point-to-point resolution of 0.17nm. The sample was sonicated in an ethanol solution, and a drop was deposited onto a copper grid covered with a holey carbon membrane for observation. Temperature-programmed oxidation was determined in a Micromeritics ASAP-2100 setup equipped with a multichannel mass spectrometer. The typical sample with 5mg was loaded in the reactor and then flushed with 1% O2/He mixture (25mL/min) at room temperature (RT) for 30min. The temperature was raised from RT to 900°C at a heating rate of 10°C/min. The evolved species were monitored with m/e intensities for 2 (H2), 18 (H2O), 28 (CO) and 44 (CO2), respectively. 2.3 Catalytic activity measurements The steam-free ethylbenzene dehydrogenation reaction was carried out in a fixed-bed continuous flow reactor under atmospheric pressure. The catalyst (300mg) is loaded onto a quartz fritted disk located inside a tubular quartz reactor (id: 8×800mm). Helium gas was fed into the reactor at a flow rate of 30mL/min through a mass flow controller (BROOKS MFC) and passed through a glass evaporator filled with liquid EB maintained at 40°C (EB partial pressure of 2922Pa) using an automatic thermal regulated bath. The reaction system was heated to 550°C and kept for 2h under He. The reactant flow (2.8vol.% EB diluted in helium and total flow rate of 30mL/min) was then fed to the reactor. The reactant and the products (styrene (ST), benzene (BZ) and toluene (TOL)) exit from the reactor were analyzed online with a PERICHROM (PR 2100) gas chromatography equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID) and CP WAX S2CB column which was previously calibrated. In order to avoid any possible condensation of the reactant or the products, all the tube lines were wrapped with a heating wire maintaining at 110°C. The ethylbenzene conversion (X EB) and styrene selectivity (S ST) were evaluated using Eqs. (1) and (2): (1) X EB = F 0 C EB,inlet − F C EB,outlet F 0 C EB,inlet × 100 % (2) S ST = C ST,outlet C ST,outlet + C TOL,outlet + C BZ,outlet × 100 % where F and F 0 are the flow rates of the outlet and inlet, respectively, and C EB, C ST, C TOL and C BZ represent the concentrations of ethylbenzene, styrene, toluene and benzene. The specific styrene yield is expressed as the amount of styrene produced per gram of active compounds per hour (mmolST/gAC/h). The carbon balances amounted to ≥96% in all investigations. The results are obtained after more than 20h on stream with stable catalytic performance under testing conditions. 3 Results and discussion The β-SiC foam was synthesized by a gas–solid reaction from a solid mixture of silicon, carbon black and solid resin at temperature ca. 1350°C under argon flow [15,34]. Low magnification SEM micrograph (Fig. 1a) shows the high porosity of the SiC foam. SEM micrograph also evidences the highly porous structure of the SiC foam with a bimodal pore size distribution, i.e. meso- and macropores (Fig. 1b and Table 1 ). Typical SEM and TEM micrographs of commercial NDs are present in Supplementary Material, Fig. S1. SEM micrograph (Fig. S1a) evidences the presence of ND aggregates with an average size of around 200nm. The ND particles with size of 4–8nm can be collected with the assistance of sonication treatment in ethanol medium, as shown in the TEM images (Fig. S1b). Figs. 1c and d and S2 show the SEM images of ND anchored on the different porous macroscopic SiC materials (foam, grains and powder). The ND loading was set at 13wt%. The low-magnification SEM image (Fig. 1c) indicates that NDs are homogeneously coated on the surface of the porous β-SiC foam. The same ND dispersion can be also found when the NDs were loaded on the SiC grains (Supplementary Material, Fig. S2a and b) and powder (Fig. S2c and d). The high-magnification SEM image (Fig. 1d) reveals that ND particles are uniformly dispersed on the surface of the porous layer of SiC. TEM images of ND/SiC foam presented in Fig. 1e and f also clearly show that NDs are well anchored on the SiC surface, which is in good agreement with the SEM results. It is worthy to note that the used SiC contains a thin layer of SiO2 on the surface, which could play a role of washcoat layer for the anchorage and dispersion of ND particles. The advantage of such washcoat layer for anchoring metal nanoparticles has already been reported in our previous publications [15,35]. In Fig. 1g, the typical 4–8nm ND particles on the SiC surface are detected by a high-resolution TEM. The HRTEM images show the (111) orientation of commercial diamond with an interplanar spacing of about 0.206nm [36,37]. It is worth noting that nanodiamond particles are typical polyhedral shape with sp3 carbon as core and graphitic carbon (sp2 carbon) or amorphous carbon that is consisted of dangling bonds terminated by functional groups as shell [10,38]. The sp2-hybridized or amorphous carbon on the surface of NDs could also act as the active site for the dehydrogenation reaction [38]. The specific surface area and pore size distribution of the ND/SiC composites are analyzed by the nitrogen sorption measurements, and the results are displayed in Table 1 and Fig. 2 . Indeed, the industry K-Fe catalyst displays the specific surface area of 4m2 /g by the measurement of N2 adsorption and desorption technique. The SiC foam (SiC(F)) has a medium specific surface area of 28m2 /g and mainly consists of meso- and macroporous network (pore size of 10–100nm), which significantly contribute to reduce the diffusion problem through the catalyst matrix. The deposition of ND particles onto the SiC foam support leads to an increase of both the final specific surface area (S BET) and total pore volume (V total) of the composite compared with the pristine SiC foam (Table 1). The S BET values of 13wt% ND/SiC(F) and 33wt% ND/SiC(F) composites are 73 and 159m2/g, respectively, whereas the initial surface area of the SiC foam is about 28m2/g. The corresponding V total also significantly increases to 0.26 and 0.33cm3/g, respectively. During the deposition process, part of the NDs can be localized within the meso- and macropores of the SiC support. Such pores filling will contribute to the creation of a new porous network with a final pore size smaller than the ones of the pristine support. It is thus expected that at high ND loading, part of the porosity of the SiC support will be completely filled by the ND, and thus the available active sites will be reduced accordingly leading to a catalyst with lower DH activity. However, as the ND mass loading increases to 44wt%, the S BET decreases to 152m2/g and the V total value changes from 0.33 to 0.64cm3/g. These results could be explained by the fact that at high NDs loading, the pore volume of the SiC was completely filled by the NDs and forms the new porosity network (the V total of pure NDs up to 1.27cm3/g) which would lead less accessible for the reactant. At high NDs loading, one should also expect that the dispersion is decreased and ND aggregates are formed, as Supplementary Material, Fig. S3 presents SEM images of the 33wt% ND/SiC(F) and 44wt % ND/SiC(F). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) is used to characterize the surface chemical composition of different NDs supported on SiC foam. The atomic ratios of carbon, oxygen and silicon obtained by XPS are summarized in Table 1, and related XPS spectra are presented in Fig. 3 . The spectra for the ND/SiC(F) samples with different loading showed O1s, C1s and Si1s peaks at 530, 286 and 101eV, respectively [32,34,39]. The surface oxygen content ranges from 11.4 to 13.0at.% as a function of the ND loading. The pure SiC has 36at.% surface oxygen due to the presence of an amorphous phase thin layer of the SiO2 and SiO x C y compound mixture [15,26]. However, these oxygenated functional groups present on the SiC surface are relatively marginal as blank test carried out on the SiC support only showed a relatively low DH performance (see the catalytic results). The oxygenated functional groups present on the SiC surface are mostly involved as anchorage sites for improving the dispersion of the deposited ND. It is also expected that the strong anchorage of the ND particles on the SiO2 layer of SiC could prevent ND particles movement and as a consequence, significantly lower the sintering process. Similar results have already been reported elsewhere [15,26]. The Si peak becomes much smaller as the NDs loading increases, which could be attributed to an extensive coverage of the SiC surface by the NDs. The Si/C ratio significantly decreases as a function of the NDs loading, i.e. from 1.22 for pure SiC to 0.02 for the 44wt% ND on SiC (Fig. 3), which could be attributed to the higher coverage or plugging of the SiC surface by NDs particles. In order to quantify the pressure drop across different composites measurements (ΔP/L) are carried out and the results are presented in Fig. 4 . The experimental pressure drop (ΔP) across various shapes of β-SiC-supported ND catalysts per unit length as a function of linear gas velocity (u g) is displayed, which is the typical model of pressure drop measurement reported elsewhere in the literatures [40–42]. According to the results, we can clearly observe that when the gas shuttles crossing the powder-like SiC or grains SiC-supported ND, a large pressure drop was observed, especially at higher gas velocity. In contrast, the SiC foam composite displays an extremely low pressure drop for the whole range of linear gas velocities. At high gas velocity, i.e. 3m/s, pressure drop is only 0.067×105 Pa/m of ND/SiC foam, whereas for the ND supported on SiC grains, a pressure drop higher than 6.8×105 Pa/m was observed. Moreover, the pressure drop of powder-like SiC-supported ND materials is even higher than 12×105 Pa/m at the gas velocity of 1.8m/s. Such result again confirms the advantage of using SiC foam structure for fixed-bed reaction. As catalyst supports for packed bed reactors, foam-structured supports with lower pressure drop, high effective surface area and high mixing degree area are of great interest for industrial applications [26,41,43,44]. The pressure drop results clearly indicate that the direct use of NDs (∅ ranged between 4 and 8nm) or the powder-like carriers supported catalysts (powder, grains, etc.) in a fixed-bed reactor configuration are problematic due to the high pressure drop across the catalyst bed even at a low gaseous space velocity. The steam-free, direct dehydrogenation of ethylbenzene reaction is performed on the ND-decorated porous SiC foam catalyst (with ND loadings of 13, 33 and 44wt%, respectively) as well as commercial nanodiamond under atmosphere pressure at 550°C at a gaseous space velocity of 30mL/min. The dehydrogenation activity (styrene yield, expressed as styrene products per gram of nanodiamonds per hour) is expressed in terms of mmolST/gND/h recorded on SiC-based catalysts with different ND loadings, pristine NDs and SiC foam support, and the results are presented in Fig. 5a and b. The DH activity gradually decreases as ND loading on the SiC foam surface increases which is directly related to the lower dispersion of NDs onto the SiC surface at high loading (Fig. 5a). The highest DH activity is obtained with the 13wt% ND/SiC under the reaction conditions used. When NDs are dispersed on the surface of porous SiC foam, the ND/SiC foam composites present relative higher activity per weight of NDs compared with pure NDs catalyst, especially at ND mass loading at 13wt%, the styrene production yield shows about 3.8 times of that on pure NDs without losing the selectivity. Taking into account these results, the optimization tests will be further carried out on the 13wt% ND/SiC catalyst. On the SiC foam supported 13wt% NDs catalyst, the styrene rate is significantly improved on the basis of the effective weight of the NDs, i.e. 12.86mmolST/gND/h, and the styrene selectivity is as high as pure NDs (98.3% of styrene selectivity; the other products consisted of light hydrocarbons such as benzene and toluene). It also can be found in Fig. 5b that the SiC materials perform almost no catalytic activity under the tested reaction conditions, thus confirming the chemical inertness character of the support. The conversion of ethylbenzene over SiC only achieves 7% (styrene rate on per weight of SiC catalyst is 0.54mmolST /gcat/h), with styrene selectivity of 88%. In the meantime, the styrene rate obtained on the unsupported commercial ND amounted to about 2.89mmolST /gcat /h at the steady state after 50h on stream, and styrene selectivity remains as high as 99%, displaying results similar to those already reported in the literature [6,45]. The steam-free DH tests are also carried out over the ND/SiC catalysts using the SiC in different shapes (powder (P), grains (G) and foam (F)), and the results are presented in Fig. 5c. The selectivity towards styrene is extremely high over all the tested catalysts. The NDs supported on SiC foam exhibit an extremely high stability as a function of time on stream compared with the other catalysts. The activity improvement of the ND/SiC foam could be attributed to the higher dispersion of ND on the SiC surface which provides a higher density of active sites for the reaction and also to the possible microturbulence generated through the contact between the reactant and the SiC foam structures. The catalytic stability of the ND/SiC (13wt%) catalyst is also evaluated during a long-term test (>100h), and the results are presented in Fig. 5d. According to the experimental results, a slow decline in the DH activity is observed on the ND/SiC catalyst at the first 40h of test and then remains almost unchanged for the whole test. As pointed out in Fig. 5d, the DH activity of the ND/SiC foam still remains at about 10.97mmolST /gND/h with the styrene selectivity of 98% after 100h of reaction, which renders it a promising catalyst for further industrial development. The high resistance towards deactivation of ND/SiC(F) could be attributed to the open porosity of the support and a connected pore which significantly reduces the residence time of the products on or next to the active site and as a consequence, the amount of carbonaceous deposit . It is worthy to note here that the pressure drop is not momentous under the laboratory-scale conditions but will be severe under the industrial conditions when hundreds kilograms of catalysts are loaded. Fig. 6 summarized the ethylbenzene DH catalytic performance on the steady state on pure NDs and different NDs loaded on the SiC foam, as well as the other carbon-based catalysts, ND supported on commercial SiO2 carrier and industrial K-Fe/Al2O3 (with 90wt% of iron loading) catalysts. For comparison, the DH activity of the ND loaded on few-layer-graphene (16wt% ND/FLG) is also reported in the same figure [46]. The industrial K-Fe/Al2O3 catalyst exhibits a high DH activity at the beginning of the test, followed by a rapid deactivation before reaching a steady state at around 1.0mmolST /gcat /h. Such deactivation phenomenon can be attributed to the active site plugging by carbonaceous residue during the course of the reaction in the absence of steam in the processing feed. The unsupported NDs present the best DH activity (2.89mmolST /gcat /h) compared to the other carbon-based catalysts and to the industrial K-Fe catalyst, which show similar catalytic behaviour as reported in [6]. The benchmarking tests carried out on different ND-based catalysts have shown that the 13wt% ND/SiC catalyst displays a highest DH activity compared to the others. The insulator carrier such as porous SiO2 is also applied for supporting NDs, and the DH results obtained are further compared with those of the different ND-based catalysts. It can be found in Fig. 6 that the NDs dispersed on the supports result in the higher DH activity compared with the one on the pristine ND, either thermal supports, i.e. FLG and SiC, or insulator supports, i.e. SiO2. Such results could be attributed to the medium loading and also to the high dispersion of the ND on the catalyst, which provide higher reactive sites for the reaction. For catalysts with higher ND loadings, the ND nanoparticles are less dispersed and thus lead to a lower DH activity. Work is ongoing to optimize the dispersion step, i.e. solvent nature or deposition process, in order to improve the styrene production per weight of the loaded catalyst. The ND/FLG (16wt% of ND) catalyst showed a slightly similar dehydrogenation performance compared with that of ND/SiC (with 13wt% of ND loading) under the same reaction conditions. In the meantime, the ND/SiO2 catalyst shows a much lower DH activity compared to the ND/SiC catalysts. According to the results, one can state that when the NDs are dispersed on thermally conductive supports, either on FLG or SiC, the dehydrogenation performance is higher compared to those supported on insulator supports. Such results could be attributed to the better homogenization of the temperature within the catalyst bed, which is not the case for the insulator catalysts in which temperature drops, due to the endothermic character of the reaction and the absence of steam in the feed as a heat carrier could lower the DH activity. However, for the industrial application, the macroscopic SiC would be more benefit compared to the ND/FLG as it allows the reduction of pressure drop across the catalyst bed and also for the cost of production of the support. The summarized dehydrogenation performance obtained on different ND and industrial K-Fe catalysts is shown in Table 2 . The catalytic activity is defined as the amount of styrene produced per hour per weight of the active phase or per amount of specific surface area. It can be found that the dispersed ND (ND/SiC) catalyst displays higher activity value per amount of NDs than that of prisitine ND and industrial K-Fe catalysts, which are also illustrated in Figs. 5 and 6. As different catalysts present different active site densities, the relative areal activity should also be taken into account for the future development of the active catalysts. The dispersed ND catalyst (13wt% ND/SiC(F)) presents a relative areal activity as high as 0.0087mmolST/m2/h at a reaction temperature of 550°C, which displays the best DH value among the ND-based, but lower areal activity than the industrial K-Fe, catalysts. It is worth to note that the specific surface area of the K-Fe catalyst is very low, i.e. 4m2/g, compared to that of the ND-based catalysts and thus, which leads to a high DH rate per surface unit. However, for the industrial application, the specific rate per weight of the catalyst is the most critical factor. The EB dehydrogenation of the 13wt% ND/SiC(F) catalyst is also performed at a reaction temperature of 600°C and compared with the one obtained over the K-Fe catalyst (Fig. 7 and Table 2). According to the results, the 13wt% ND/SiC(F) catalyst displays an EB conversion of 54.7%, with a relatively high styrene selectivity of 92.6% (Fig. 7). In contrast, under the same reaction conditions, the K-Fe-based catalyst shows only an EB conversion of 24.3% and styrene selectivity of only 81.6%. As shown in Table 2, the styrene formation rate of the 13wt% ND/SiC(F) catalyst is about 3.8mmolST/gcatalyst/h, which is more than two times the activity of the K-Fe-based catalyst. The temperature-programmed oxidation (TPO) combined with mass spectrometry is also performed on the ND/SiC (13wt%) catalyst before and after EB dehydrogenation test (Fig. 8 ) to evidence the low carbonaceous deposit and to better explain the high stability of the catalyst for the long-term test. For comparison, the spent industrial K-Fe-based catalyst is also analyzed, and the results are compared with those of the ND/SiC catalyst (Fig. 8b). It can be found in the figures that the spent ND/SiC(F) catalyst showed similar combustion profiles in the temperature range from 500 to 700°C, which can be issued from the oxidation of NDs. The low CO2 intensity at temperatures between 400 and 450°C is attributed to the organic compounds and low-temperature coke deposition during the long-term DH reaction. On the contrary, the spent industrial K-Fe2O3 catalyst shows obviously a large amount of deposit coke as the intensity of the CO2 peaks steadily increased, especially at temperatures higher than 500°C, which could be attributed to the irreversible or inert coke [47]. This could be the major reason for the low activity obtained from metal-based catalysts due to the coke deposition, which severely blocked most of the active surface under steam-free reaction conditions. The ND/SiC catalyst is also tested for the regeneration process by diluted oxygen at 450°C in order to understand the catalytic performance over this type of hybrid composite as a function of regeneration cycles. Based on the TPO-MS results, it can be found that the organic compounds and low-temperature carbonaceous deposits could be fully removed by oxygen during the oxidative regeneration step. This coverage could be attributed to the sharp deactivation at the beginning of the test. As explained in the previous research work by XPS, XRD, TPO-MS and TEM techniques on the fresh and spent ND/FLG catalysts [46], the first period of deactivation could be attributed to the formation of low-temperature coke on the surface of the active sites and some carbon allotropes rearrangement during the reaction. The equilibrium is achieved afterwards by reaction between the low-temperature coke with H2 generated from the dehydrogenation process, and then further sharp deactivation is unlikely to occur. Moreover, as one can observe, such deactivation becomes less pronounced after repeated regeneration, which probably modifies the surface structure of the catalyst leading to a more stable catalyst as a function of time on stream (Fig. 9 ). Such deactivation period could be significantly shorter after some regeneration and will not represent a real problem for the process as almost no deactivation was observed afterwards on the regenerated catalyst. As shown in Fig. 9, similar DH activities are observed over the ND/SiC catalyst after three regeneration cycles lasting for a total of 300h. More interestingly, the regenerated catalyst also displays high stability over more than 150h time on stream at the single regeneration run, which is also one of the prerequisites for developing the future direct dehydrogenation catalysts. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, we successfully prepared the macroscopic ND/β-SiC porous hybrid composite via a facile one-step method. The ND particles are uniformly dispersed on the surface of the porous SiC foam network, displaying a highly effective surface area for the steam-free dehydrogenation reaction along with a low pressure drop which is of extreme interest when operated in large-scale industrial fixed-bed reactors. The ND/SiC foam displays a styrene production rate of 12.86mmolST /gND/h along with a styrene selectivity of 98% at 550°C. Such performance leads to a styrene production rate of about more than 10 times higher than the commercial K-Fe-based catalyst and 3.8 times higher than the pure ND powder. The ND/SiC catalyst also displays an extremely high stability as a function of time on stream, i.e. more than 100h, unlikely to the metal-based catalysts. Such high stability is attributed to the open porosity of the catalyst, which efficiently prevents coke deposition during the course of the reaction. It is expected that such hybrid catalysts could also be used in other applications reaching far beyond the catalysis field, i.e. bacterial removal [48] or chemical sensor. Work is ongoing to evaluate such structured catalysts in a more drastic reaction condition, i.e. high partial pressure of EB and high space velocity. coredata.dc:description: Nanodiamonds (NDs), a typical sp3-like carbon, have an average size less than 10nm with a large surface-to-volume ratio, which contributes to a high surface activity than other types of carbon. However, the powder form of the material renders it difficult to use in large-scale applications, especially in the field of heterogeneous catalysis in which high pressure drop across the catalytic bed and difficulty of handling powder are the main drawbacks. In this work, a new hybrid structure consisting of nanodiamond-decorated porous β-SiC foam matrix has been investigated as a metal-free catalyst in the steam-free dehydrogenation of ethylbenzene into styrene. The hybrid foam catalyst displays an excellent catalytic specific rate and stability in the direct catalytic dehydrogenation of ethylbenzene (EB) to styrene. The dehydrogenation activity (12.87mmolST/gND /h, moles styrene products per gram of nanodiamonds per hour) is about 10 times higher with respect to the commercial K-Fe-based catalyst and 3.8 times higher than that of powder-form NDs without losing styrene selectivity (SST =98%) and thus demonstrates the high catalytic efficiency of this metal-free catalyst for the studied reaction. This study shows a new development towards the practical use of such structured composite catalysts in the field of catalysis where high performance and stable catalyst are still under scrutiny.
coredata.dc:title: Macroscopic nanodiamonds/β-SiC composite as metal-free catalysts for steam-free dehydrogenation of ethylbenzene to styrene
